Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides funding to the University of Hawaii and partners to create a Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence - Island Earth (COSEE-IE). With a broad base of collaborators in the private sector, state and federal government, formal and informal education, COSEE IE proposes to build a collaborative network that connects ocean research and teaching with traditional knowledge in order to facilitate active engagement in stewardship by all ocean users. This Center will focus on: [1] providing scientists with opportunities and guidance for improved involvement in Broader Impact activities; [2] creating opportunities for ocean scientists and groups who educate tourists in Hawaii to interact (i.e. ocean tour operators and lifeguards); and [3] connecting modern research, traditional knowledge, and ocean policy, for example by incorporating Native Hawaiian Traditional Knowledge into the COSEE Communicating Ocean Science Course.

ProgramElement.Text: CENTRES FOR OCEAN SCI EDU EXCE

ProgramReference.Text: CENTRES FOR OCEAN SCI EDU EXCE
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COSEE Island Earth program resulted in the following outcomes:

Created a sustainable web-based platform called seaHarmony to provide global opportunities for university and agency scientists to engage in community outreach and collaboration. 

Provided opportunies for informal educators to improve their understanding and skills in effective science communication and teaching practices.

Integrated communication, pedagogy, and teaching skills into marine biology professional education through a career skills core course for graduate students.

Developed opportunities for pre-service and in-service teachers to deepen their pedagogical content knowledge of authentic scientific practices and habits of mind through open inquiry laboratory experiences.

Provided professional development on climate science and adapatation to Pacific Island science teachers via week-long Climate Science Teacher Institutes

Developed a continuing marine-themed radio program that provides public awareness of current conservation and management issues in Hawaii.

Engaged public audiences in meaningful and open disucssion about science, culture and society via community-based HISci Cafes.

Developed and distributed Tradtional Knowledge Teaching Boxes across the main Hawaiian Islands to help integrate traditional knowledge and sciences in classroom learning. 

Provided opportunities for graduate students in Ocean Sciences and Hawaiian Knowledge to work together on collaborative projects that bridge disciplinary boundaries and develop deeper understanding of different knowledge systems.

Contributed to knowledge transfer and dissemination by presenting COSEE work in peer-reviewed journals and at professional conferences.

Improved public understanding of ocean sciences through educational presentations at public events.
